evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the historical timeframe t3 prefinal phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal data, showing consistent patterns and no contradictory information.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3 prefinal phase, including timing, crew roles, and operational context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the historical timeframe t3 prefinal phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: Crew communication is adequately represented by the statements of the tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, and wingman
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If crew had clearly communicated and coordinated to stop the pushback timely

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence from H8, H10, and H12 shows that communication and coordination among the crew broke down during the pushback, as key crew members did not warn or question the instructor despite the aircraft passing the TRP and colliding with the blast fence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcripts or recordings of communications; reliance on post-event statements

This indicates the deviation is documented and accessible within the operational safety database.
outcome.uncertainty_source: The evidence does not explicitly state the existence or accessibility of a formal operational safety database entry; it is inferred from detailed history documentation.

The timing references (e.g., positions relative to stands and TRP) are sufficient to establish alignment with key features.
defeaters: If evidence showed the procedural deviation was due to factors unrelated to timing, crew actions, or environmental conditions observed in this case.
If the crew actions or environmental conditions were significantly different from those described in the evidence.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes the timing, crew actions, and environmental conditions during the pushback, showing the procedural deviation aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal (H2, H3, H4, H8, H10, H12, H13).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit timing data or detailed environmental conditions beyond qualitative descriptions; some assumptions about alignment are inferred.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

assumptions: The TRP marking and visual signals are the primary environmental or marking deficiencies relevant to the inspection
defeaters: If there was evidence of more effective or redundant marking or signaling methods that reliably prevented pushback beyond the TRP
If training or procedures ensured all personnel consistently recognized and acted on the TRP markings and signals

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates the TRP marking exists but is small and the visual signals to stop the tug are insufficient and not always noticed (H7, H8, H13), suggesting the identification of the environmental or marking deficiency is not fully robust against potential defeaters during the inspection.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in how well the TRP marking and signals are perceived and acted upon in practice

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25 is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure would be explicitly reported or evidenced
Human factors and communication issues are considered defeaters to mechanical failure
defeaters: If direct mechanical or control system failure evidence were found
If evidence showed the tug or aircraft controls malfunctioned
If communication or human error was ruled out conclusively

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite the tug instructor's control and signals (H4, H8, H12). The trainee and other operators did not intervene or warn, indicating possible human factors rather than mechanical/control failure. No direct evidence of mechanical/control failure is present, so defeaters (human error or communication issues) are plausible, reducing resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical failure evidence; ambiguity whether failure was mechanical or human error

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal is robust against common defeaters such as data inconsistencies, reporting errors, and alternative explanations.

assumptions: Personnel statements are accurate and truthful
The TRP location and markings are correctly identified and understood by involved parties
No other unreported factors influenced the pushback execution
defeaters: If new evidence showed data inconsistencies or reporting errors in the accounts of the tug instructor, trainee, headset operator, or wingman
If alternative explanations for the pushback continuation beyond the TRP were provided and supported by evidence
If the TRP markings or procedures were ambiguous or misunderstood by the involved personnel

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents the procedural deviation (H4) and shows that common defeaters such as alternative explanations or reporting errors are unlikely because multiple qualified personnel (H8, H10, H12) did not warn or question the deviation, indicating consistent and reliable observations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit data validation or cross-checking in the evidence; reliance on personnel statements without independent verification

node.statement: Crew did not effectively coordinate tasks and responsibilities during flight operations

Effective coordination would have prevented the aircraft moving beyond the TRP
defeaters: If evidence showed proactive communication or warnings from crew members preventing the incident
If the crew roles and responsibilities were clearly defined and followed during the operation

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

node.statement: Crew members failed to share critical flight information in a timely manner

assumptions: The TRP location and its importance were known to all crew members
Failure to warn about passing the TRP constitutes failure to share critical flight information
defeaters: If evidence showed that timely warnings were given but ignored or misunderstood
If communication protocols were ambiguous or not expected in this context
If the crew roles did not require sharing such information

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly indicate that crew members (trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) failed to share critical flight information (e.g., warning about passing the TRP) in a timely manner, contributing to the collision.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing explicit communication transcripts or recordings

node.statement: Misinterpretation or misunderstanding of communicated information occurred among crew members

defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, clear communication and mutual understanding among crew members about the pushback status and TRP limits.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows crew members had differing assumptions and did not communicate warnings or concerns about the pushback continuing past the TRP, indicating misinterpretation or misunderstanding of communicated information.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No recordings or transcripts of actual communications; reliance on post-event statements may omit some communication details.

children_spec.statement: The procedural deviation was not corrected by the flight crew during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recordings and crew reports to determine if any corrective actions were taken during pushback

children_spec.statement: Ground personnel did not intervene to prevent or correct the procedural deviation during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine ground crew communications and procedures to verify if intervention occurred

children_spec.statement: The aircraft systems did not provide alerts or warnings that prevented the procedural deviation during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze aircraft system logs and alert records for warnings related to pushback procedures

node.statement: The procedural deviation was not corrected by the flight crew during pushback

assumptions: The tug instructor is considered part of the flight crew for the purpose of correction during pushback
No other unseen corrective actions were taken by the flight crew
defeaters: If evidence showed the flight crew actively intervened to stop the pushback before the collision
If the tug instructor had communicated a valid reason for continuing beyond the TRP
If the trainee or headset operator had issued warnings or taken corrective action

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4), indicating the pushback was not stopped at the procedural limit. The tug instructor only stopped the tug after the collision (H5). The trainee driver expected the instructor to stop but did not intervene (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor had a reason for continuing (H12). This shows the procedural deviation was not corrected by the flight crew during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement that the flight crew attempted to correct the deviation; reliance on indirect inference from actions and assumptions of involved personnel

node.statement: The aircraft systems did not provide alerts or warnings that prevented the procedural deviation during pushback

assumptions: No other unreported aircraft system alerts or warnings existed during the pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed the aircraft systems provided alerts or warnings that were ignored or overridden
If crew or ground personnel reported receiving alerts or warnings from aircraft systems during pushback

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The tug instructor explicitly stated no warnings or alerts were received from the wingman or headset operator before the collision (H8), and the headset operator did not question the instructor's actions despite the aircraft moving beyond the TRP (H12), indicating no system alerts or warnings prevented the procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of aircraft system alerts or warnings in the evidence; reliance on human reports and observations

she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any physical obstructions or blockages in the mechanical control pathways; detection of obstructions would reduce availability

children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control inputs and control surfaces; disconnections or misalignments would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are not seized or jammed
children_spec.test_procedure: Test the movement of mechanical control components for free operation; any seizure or jamming would reduce availability

node.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical components were missing or damaged
Inspection reports confirming mechanical component status
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates the physical presence or intactness of mechanical components required for control.
